story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in the Philippines, there was a kind and curious little girl named Alingning. She lived with her family in a humble nipa hut near the edge of the forest. Alingning loved to explore the world around her, always asking questions and seeking out new adventures.

One day, Alingning heard about a magical creature that lived deep in the forest, called the "Nuno sa Punso." The Nuno sa Punso was a tiny old man who lived inside anthills, and was said to have great power.

Alingning was fascinated by this story, and decided that she must find the Nuno sa Punso and see if it was true. She packed a small bag with some food and water, and set off into the forest.

As she walked deeper into the woods, Alingning came across many strange and wonderful sights. She saw colorful birds and butterflies, and even a family of mischievous monkeys. But she didn't see any sign of the Nuno sa Punso.

Just when Alingning was about to give up, she stumbled upon the most magnificent anthill she had ever seen. It was tall and grand, with hundreds of tiny doors and windows. And there, sitting on top of the anthill, was the Nuno sa Punso himself!

The Nuno sa Punso was smaller than Alingning had imagined, but he had a long white beard and kind eyes. He smiled at Alingning and said, "Welcome, little one. I have been expecting you. What brings you to my home?"

Alingning told the Nuno sa Punso that she had heard the stories about him and wanted to see if they were true. The Nuno sa Punso chuckled and said, "Yes, I do have some power, but only to protect the creatures of the forest. And in return, they help me by bringing me food and shelter."

Alingning was amazed and asked if she could help, too. The Nuno sa Punso smiled and said, "Of course, little one. If you are kind and respectful to the creatures of the forest, they will be kind and respectful to you."

Alingning promised to be kind and left the forest, feeling happy and fulfilled. From that day on, she treated all living things with love and respect, and the creatures of the forest returned the favor.

And so, Alingning lived happily ever after, always remembering the lesson she learned from the Nuno sa Punso in the forest: to be kind and respectful to all creatures, and to always seek out new adventures with an open heart.

Goodnight, my dear daughter, sleep well and remember to be kind and curious, just like Alingning.
